availability.p: Downloading shall be restricted to one copy for private use.

monogr.author: Unknown
monogr.title: Four Romances of England: King Horn, Havelok the Dane, Bevis of Hampton, Athelston

projectDesc.p: The Middle English Texts Series offers a diverse and representative array of literary texts that medieval readers in the present-day British Isles would have encountered between the twelfth and sixteenth centuries. It is committed to making available both affordable print and open access editions to scholars, teachers, and students of the Western Middle Ages. In its digital publications, the series prioritizes a user-friendly interface and viewing options, multiple downloadable formats, enhanced searchability and filtering, and accessibility to the widest possible range of users.

editorialDecl.p: METS takes as its mission the creation of affordable editions that would pass scrutiny from the most demanding expert, yet would prove comprehensible, and even enticing, to someone who had never read Middle English before. This agenda dictates that METS publications offer not a critical edition reflecting all surviving manuscripts, and certainly not a diplomatic edition, but a best-text edition, informed by the notes and apparatus of earlier editions (where these exist), and by substantive variants from other manuscript witnesses. Transcriptions of Middle English texts are lightly modernized to ensure a smooth reading experience, while non-English texts preserve both the original language and a modern English translation in facing-page format. Each edition offers expert assistance with language and lexicon, providing glosses alongside the text(s), textual and explanatory notes, elucidation of unfamiliar contexts and traditions, and thematic and interpretive possibilities. All editions feature general introductions that set the edited text within its own time, place, and traditions, and link it to ancestor, congener, and successor materials. All publications contain comprehensive, current bibliographies of pertinent scholarship and criticism. House style is adapted from the Chicago Manual of Style.

correction.p: This text may include corrections made after the original edition went to press in order to correct errors and improve glosses. For a full list of editorial and typographical corrections made to this edition, please view its correction log on Github: https://github.com/mets-editions/herzman-fourromances/blob/main/herzman-fourromances-export-corrections-log.xlsx

lg.l: ThatG to my song lythe!N G[Who] listen
A sang ichT schal you singe
King he was biwesteN Gin the west
So longe so hitG laste.T it (i.e., his life)
He hadde a sone that het Horn;
Fairer ne mighte non beoG born,N be
Ne no rein upon birine,Grain fell upon
Ne sunne upon bischine.Gor sun shone
Fairer nis non thane he was:
He was bright soG the glas;as
He was whit so the flur;Gflower
He was fayr and ekeG bold,also
And of fiftene winter hold.T Gold
In none kinge richeGno other kingdom
Nas non his iliche.Ganyone like him
That he alle with him ladde,Gled
And alle hiG were faire gomes,Gtheygood fellows
That on him het HathulfG child,one of them was called Athulf
Hit was upon a someres day,
Also ichG you telle may,As I
Rod on his pleingN GRode for sport
Ase he was wonedG ride.used to
Al toG fewe ware tho!T Gtoo were they
He axedeG what hi soghteT Gasked they sought
A payn hit ofherde,Gpagan heard it
And alle that CristN luveth upon
Ne shaltuG todai henneG gon.”Nor shall you hence
The king alighte ofG his stede,N off
For thoG he havedeG nede,then had
Al to fewe he hadde tho.Gthen
ThatG sume hit yfelde.GSo that felt
The king hadde al to fewe
Togenes so fele schrewe;GAgainst so many villains
The pains comeG to londepagans came
And neme hit in here hondeGtook it into their possession
That folcG hi gunne quelle,Gfolk kill
And churchen for to felle.Gchurches to destroy
Ther ne moste libbeGmight not live
The fremdeG ne the sibbe.N Gstrangers relatives
Bute hi here laye asoke,GUnless they their religion forsook
For Murri heo weopG soreshe wept
Aghenes the paynes forbode.GAgainst the pagans’ injunction
That no payn hit ne wiste.GSo that no pagan knew it
Evre heo badG for Horn childEver she prayed
That Jesu Crist him beo myld.Gmight be gracious to him
Horn was in paynes hondeGhands of the pagans
With his ferenG of the londe.companions
Payns him wolde slen,Gwanted to kill him
Other al quic flen,GOr flay him alive
Yef his fairnesse nere:GIf it were not for
YefG thu mote to live goGIf were to go away alive
Ye scholdeG slenG us alle:might slay
TharvoreG thu mostG to stere,N GTherefore must go boat
To schupeG schulle ye funde,Gship hurry
And sinke to the grunde.Gbottom [of the sea]
The se you schal adrenche,Gdrown in
Ne schal hit us noght ofthinche.GNor shall [we] regret it
And thi fader deth abeie.”Gpay for
The childrenN hi broghte to stronde,Gshore
Ofte hadde Horn beo wo,Gbeen woeful
AcG nevre wurs than him was tho.T GBut then
And Horn child to rowe;Grue (regret bitterly)
The se that schup so fasste drofGdrove
Hi wenden towisseGThey expected for certain
Of here lif to misse,Gtheir life to lose
Al the day and al the night
Til Horn saghG on the strondeGsaw shore
Men gonG in the londe.N going about
Blithe beo we on lyve;GLet us be happy [to be] alive
Ure schupG is on ryve.”GOur ship shore
OfG schup hi gunne funde,GOff they hasten
And setten fout to grunde.Gfoot to ground
No water the nadrinke.Ghave you to drink
GretG thu wel of myne kenne,GGreet family
And seieG the paeneG king,say to pagan
That ich am holG and ferGsound well
And seie that heiG schal fondeGthey experience
The dentG of myne honde.”T blow
The children yede to tune,Gwent their way
Hy metten with Almair King,GKing Alymar
He him spacG to Horn childspoke
“WhannesG beo ye, faire gumes,GWhence (from where) young ones
That her to londe beoth icume,Ghave come
A swichG fair veradeGvery group of companions
Ne saugh ich in noneG stunde,never
Bi westene londe:Gland of the west
SeieG me wat ye seche.”GTell seek
VorG so hit moste bivalle:GFor befall
And dudenG hem of lyve.Gdeprived life
So Crist me mote rede,GSo help me God
WithG the se to pleie,GOn sport
DaiG hit is igon and other,G[One] day another
UreG schip bigan to swymmeGOur drift
NuG thu might us slenG and bindeNow slay
Bute yef hit beo thi wille,
IwisG he nas no nithingGtruly villain
“SeieG me, child, what is thi name?Tell
Sone soG he hit herde:As soon as
Icomen utG of the bote,GCome out boat
Kyng, wel mote thee tide.”Gyou prosper
Thanne hym spak the gode king,
“Well brucG thu thin evening.N Gbear name
Bi dales and bi hulle;T Ghill
Horn, thu lude sune,Gloudly shall sound
Ne may ich the forlete.”Gnot abandon you
And Horn midG him, his fundling,N Gwith foundling
That was stiwardG of his hus.steward
Of wudeG and of rivere,Ghunting hawking
Thu tech him of alle the listeGskills
That thu evre of wiste,Gknew about
And his feirenT G thou wiseGcompanions teach
And tech him of harpe and songe.”
Horn in herteG laghteGin his heart understood
In the curtG and ute,Gcourt out
And mest him luvede Rymenhild,GRymenhild loved him the most
He was mest in thoghte;Gforemost in her thoughts
That negh heo gan wexe wild:T Gshe nearly went crazy
For heo ne mighte at bordeGdinner table
Ne nowhar in non othere stede.N Gplace
With him speke ne mighte.Gshe could not speak
Hire soreghe ne hire pineGHer sorrow nor her pain
And thus hire bithoghte tho:Gdecided then
HeoG sende hire sondeGShe her message
For heo gan to lure;Gappear downcast
For heo nas nothing blithe.Gwas not a bit well
The stward was in herte wo,Gpained in his heart
For he nusteG what to do.did not know
Gret wunder him thughte,GSeemed very strange to him
Hit nas for none gode:GIt was for no good
Thu schalt with me to bureG gonbower
To speke with Rymenhild stilleGin private
And witen hure wille.Gknow about her desire
And into bure with him yede:Gwent
Rymenhild gan wexe wild:N Ggrew very passionate
Heo wendeG that Horn hit werethought
With Athulf child he wedde;Grevealed passion
Thu schalt thi trewthe plighteGswear fidelity
On myn hond her righte,Gright here
Me to spuse holde,Gto be a spouse
And ich thee lord to wolde.”Gto have as lord
Athulf sede on hire ireGin her ear
So stille so hit were,GAs quietly as possible
For Horn nis noght her inne.
TheghG Horn were under moldeGEven if earth
OtherG elles wher he woldeOr wherever
Other henneG a thusend mile,from here
Ich nolde him ne thee bigile.”Gwould not beguile him nor you
And Athelbrus fuleG heo schente.Gfoully denounced
“HennesG thu go, thu fule theof,GFrom here wicked thief
Ne wurstuG me nevre more leof;Gwill you be dear
Went utG of my bur,GGet out bower
And on highe rode anhonge.Ggallows hang
Ne spek ich noght with Horn:
Horn is fairer thane beo he:Ghe (i.e., Athulf)
With muchel schame mote thu deie.”Gdie
Lithe me a litel throghe!GListen to me for a moment
For Horn is fair and riche,
Nis no wharG his iliche.GNowhere equal
DudeG him on mi lokyng.GPlaced care
With him ye wolden pleieN Gtake pleasure
Rymenhild, foryefG me thi tene,Gforgive anger
And Horn ich schal thee fecche,
Wham so hit recche.”GWhoever may care
Rymenhild, yef he cuthe,Gas much as she could
Gan lynne with hire muthe.Gkeep quiet
Heo makede hireG wel blithe;She made herself
Wel was hireG that sithe.G[It was] well with her time
On a squieres wise.Gdressed as a squire
To wudeG for to pleie,Gwoods sport
Nis nonG that him biwreie.GNo one will betray
Til hit beo nir eve,Gclose to evening
To haven of him mi wille;Gdesire
After ne reccheT ich what me telle.”1
Aylbrus wende hire fro;Gturned away from her
Horn in halle fond he thoGthen
To bureG nu thu wende,Gbedchamber go
In herte thu hem holde.Gthem keep (i.e., be quiet)
Ne schal hit thee nevre rewe.”Gyou will not regret it
Horn in herte leideGtook to heart
And sweteliche hure grette.Gsweetly greeted her
That the sitteth nixte.Gsit next to you
And tok him bi the honde:
Heo sette him on pelleN Gfur mantle
Of wyn to drinke his fulle:
Heo makede himG faire chereShe showed him
And tok him abute the swere.Gneck
So wel so hire luste.T Gas much as she liked
Thu schalt have me to thi wif.Gfor your wife
And plistG me thi trewthe.Gpledge oath (fidelity)
Horn tho him bithoghteGthought to himself
Ich am iboreG to loweGborn too low
Ich am icome of thralleN Ga serf
And fundling bifalle.Ghave become a foundling
Ne feolle hit the of cundeGNor would it be natural
To spuseG beo me bunde.GAs a spouse united
Hit nereG no fair weddingwould be
Bitwexe a thral and a king.”N
ThoG gan Rymenhild mislykeGThen be displeased
AdunG heo feol iswoghe.GDown fell unconscious
Horn in herte was ful woGin much grief
And tok hire on his armes two.
He gan hire for to kesseGkiss
Help me to knighteGbecome a knight
That he me yive dubbing:Gdub me
Are come seve night.GBefore a week is up
And this ryng ther uppeGalong with it
And seG he holde foreward.Gsee to it keep the agreement
Seie ich him biseche,GSay I ask him
That he adun falleGfall down (humble himself)
Hit wurth him wel iyolde.GHe will be well-rewarded
Thin erende to bede.”GMake known your business
For hit was negh eve.Gnearly evening
And yaf him thatG he broghte,gave him what
And sede him his nede,Gwhat he wanted
And bihetG him his mede.Gpromised reward
Athelbrus also switheGas soon as possible
A tale mid the beste.GThe best of all tales
Ther bihoveth geste.GIt is fitting to have a good time
Hit nere noght for lorenGIt is not a lost cause
For to knighti childG Horn,young man
GodG knight he schal yelde.”GGood turn out to be
And after wurthT G mi derling.Gbecome favorite
Alle he schal hemG knightethem all
Til the light of day sprang
Ailmar him thughte lang.Gthought to himself
Sume hiG were luthere.GSome of them evil
He sette him on a stede whit:N Gwhite horse
Ther nas noG knight hym ilik.Gwas no like him
He smot him a litel wightGlight blow
And bedG him beon a godG knight.ordered good
Athulf fel aknesG tharon his knees
Nu isG knight Sire HornNow as
Over us that bi him stonde;
Thin armes he hath and scheld
To fighte with upon the feld:
And that hire thughte seve yer.Gshe thought seven years
Hornes come hire thughte god:GHorn’s coming seemed good to her
And Athulf knight the biforn.Gbefore you
Do nu that thu er of spake:Gspoke about before
To thy wif thu me take.
Ef thu art trewe of dedes,Gi.e., a man of your word
UnbindG me of my pine.”GRelease pain
Ich wulle don al thi wille,
Also hit mot bitide.GWhen the time is right
Mid spereG I schal furst ride,With spear
ArG ich thee ginneG to woghe.GBefore begin woo
Of oG dai al isprunge;Gone sprung up
ForthiG me stondeth the more rape.N T GFor you greater haste
Ich wulle do pruesse,GI will do knightly deeds
For thi luve in the felde
If ich come to lyve,Greturn alive
Ich schal thee take to wyve.”
Ich weneG ich mai thee leve:Gbelieve love
Tak nu her this gold ring:N
GodG him is the dubbing;N GGood adornment
Ther nis non betere anonder sunneGunder the sun
That eni man of telle cunne.Gcan tell of
For my luve thu hit were
And on thi finger thu him bere.
The stones beoth of suche graceGpower
That thu ne schalt in none place
Of none duntes beon ofdrad,Gblows be afraid
Ne on batailleG beon amad,Gbattle go crazy
EfG thu loke theranGIf on it
And Sire Athulf, thi brother,G[sworn] brother
Leve at hire he nam,GHe took leave of her
Thar he tok his gode fole,Ghorse
Also blak soG eny cole.As black as
The foleG schok the brunieN Ghorse armor
That al the curtG gan denie.Gcourt resounded
He fond o schup stondeGa ship anchored
An hundG him gan biheldeOne heathen
“This lond we wullegh winneGwish to conquer
And sle thatG ther is inne.”[the inhabitants]
At evreche dunteT Geach and every blow
He sloghG ther on hasteGkilled quickly
That folc that he gan quelle.Gsubdue
Horn tok the maisteres heved,N Gleader’s head
That he hadde him birevedGdeprived of
And sette hit on his swerde,
Anoven at than orde.GOn top on the point
And alle thine knightes mitte.Gwith you
So I rod on my pleingGAs I rode for sport
I fond o schup roweGrow of ships
Mid watere al byfloweT GWith water surrounded
Mi swerd me noldeG faille:would not
I smot hem alle to grunde,
Other yaf hem dithes wunde.GOr gave them deadly wounds
Nu is thi wile iyolde,Gtrouble rewarded
King, that thu me knighty woldest.”
A moreghe thoG the day gan springe,T In the morning when
The king him rodN an huntinge.
That was the wurste moder child.N Gworst child of woman
Horn ferdeT G into bureGwent chamber
AlsoG heo were of witte.GAs if out of her mind
Heo sat on the sunneGi.e., at a sunny window
Horn sede, “Lef, thin ore!GBeloved, grant me your favor
Heo sede, “Noght I ne wepe,GI do not weep for nothing
To the seG my net I caste,sea
And hit nolde noght ilaste;Gstay intact
A gret fissG at the fursteGfish immediately
Mi net he gan to berste.Gburst
Ich weneG that ich schal leoseGknow lose
The fiss that ich wolde cheose.”
I schal me make thin oweGown
For everech othere wighte,GAbove any other creature
And tharto mi treutheG I thee plighte.”Goath pledge
And Horn let the tires stille.Gtears stop
Other sum man schal us schende.GOr someone will harm us
The fiss that brak the lyne,
YwisG he doth us pine.GCertainly torment
That schal don us tene,Gcause us pain
And wurth wel sone isene.”Gwill be seen
Aylmar rod bi Sture,N Gthe Mersey
And sede thes folye:Gspoke these lies
To bringe thee of lyve,Gto kill you
And so he doth wel ofte.
And thider thu go al right,
Thu do him utG of londe,force him out
OtherG he doth thee schonde!”GBefore harm
Wel modiG and wel murne.Gangry sorrowful
“Awey ut,”G he sede, “fule theof,Gout foul thief
Ne wurstu me nevremore leof!GNor will you ever be dear to me
Wend utG of my bureGGet out bower
Wel sone bute thu flitte,GUnless you flee at once
And his armesG he gan sprede.Garmor laid out
His brunieN G he gan lacechain mail tunic
So heG scholde in to place.GAs if he battle
Nabod he noght to longe.GHe wasted no time
The fiss that thi net rente,Gtore
Rymenhild, have wel godne day:Ghave a good day
No lengG abidenG I ne may.No longer stay
Yef I ne come ne sende,GIf I do not return or send a message
Heo custeG him wel a stundeGkissed a while
And Rymenhild feol to grunde.N Gswooned
Ne mighte he no leng bileve;Glonger stay
Kep welG mi luve newe.Take care of
Rymenhild thu kep and loke.”Glook after
To the haveneG he ferde,Gharbor went
And a godG schup he hurede,Ggood rented
And al that him isighe.Ghe saw all of that
The whyght him gan stonde,Gseabreeze sustained him
And drofG til Hirelonde.T Gdrove Ireland
That on him het Harild,Gone called himself Harold
Icomen utG of the bote,GCome out boat
Wel feor fram biwesteGFrom far away in the west
To seche mine beste.”Gseek my fortune
And tok him by the bridel:
With me thu lef a stunde.Gremain a while
Also mote I sterve,GAs surely as I must die
Ne sagh I nevre my lyveGin my life
Cutberd heo ladde in to halle,
And hi a kne gan falle:Gthey on their knees
He sette him a knewelyngGmade them kneel
And grette wel the gode king.
“Sire King, of him thu hast to done;Gdo [business] with him
BitakG him thi lond to werie;GEntrust defend
For he is the faireste man
That evre yutG on thi londe cam.”yet
Thanne sede the king so dere,
And whan thu farst to woghe,Ggo wooing
ImentG thu havest to wyve,G[Whatever] intention marry
Ne schal thee nevre wel spede.”N Gprosper
A geaunt swthe sone,Ggiant very quickly
And herkneG this tything:Glisten to message
Her buth paensG arived;There are pagans
Her beothG on the sonde,GThere are sand
Yef other thre slen ure,GIf your three slay our [one]
Yef ure onG overcometh your threo,Gour one three
Al this lond schal ureG beo.ours
Whane the light of daye springe.”
For hi beothG the strengesteN they are
Bute what schal us to rede?GWhat advice shall we take
Ich weneG we beth alle dede.”believe
The king aros amoreghe,Gthe next morning
With armes he him schredde:Gequipped himself
Horn his brunie gan on caste,Garmored corselet put on
And togare go wulle.”Gtogether will go
Right at prime tideN Gsix a.m.
Hi gunnen ut rideGThey rode out
A geaunt swthe kene,Ggiant very bold
His feren him bisideGcompanions beside him
He yaf dentes inoghe;N Genough blows
For hiG were negh aslaghe;Gthey nearly slain
One while ef you leste.”GFor a moment if you desire
Hi sede hi nevre naddeGThey never said they had
Of knighte dentesG so harde,From a knight blows
Bote ofG the King Murry,Except from
That wes switheG sturdy.T Who was very
That driven him of londGout of the land
And that his fader slogh.Gkilled his father
ToG him his swerd he drogh.Against
He smot him thureghG the herte,through
That soreG him gan to smerte.Gsorely hurt
The paensG that er were so sturneGpagans fierce
Gunne after hem wel swithe higheGin great haste
And sloghenG alle the hundesT Gkilled hounds
Er hi hereG schipes funde.GBefore they their found
To dethe he hem alle broghte.
His fader deth wel dere hi boghte.GThey paid dearly for his father’s death
Ne scathedeG werT no wighte,Gharmed not a one
ButeG his sones tweieGExcept for two
MeG leiden hem in bareGMen funeral bier
And burden hem ful yare.T Gburied them right away
Do as I schal redeG thee.advise
And thu art knight of muchel pris,Ggreat value
Mi rengneG thu schalt welde,Gkingdom rule
That sitteth on the lofte.”Gin the upper room
Thi doghter, that ye me bede,Goffer
Ower rengneG for to lede.Grealm govern
WelG more ich schal thee serve,Better
Sire Kyng, or thu sterve.Gbefore you die
Sire King, yefG me mi rente.Ggive reward
Ne shaltu me hire werne.”GNor shall you refuse me
That to Rymenild he ne senteGneither sent a message
Ne him self ne wente.Gnor returned
That wolde hire have to wyve;Gmarry
AtonG he was with the kingAgreed
A writ he dude devise;Gshe dictated
That Horn ne luvede noght lite.GWho loved Horn not a little
TherG meG him finde mighte.Where men
Til oG day that he ferdeGone went
To wudeG for to schete.Gwoods shoot
A knaveN G he gan imete.Gservant met
ForG a maiden Rymenhild,On behalf of
That for him gan wexe wild.Gis going crazy
King Modi of Reynes,N G(i.e., Furness in the northwest of England)
Nis he nowar ifunde.GHe is not to be found anywhere
Horn iherdeG with his ires,Gheard ears
And spak with bidere tires:Gbitter tears
“Knave, wel thee bitide!Ggood fortune upon you
Aghen to hureG thu turneGher return
And seie that heo nu murne,Gnot be sad
For I schal beo ther bitime,Gbe there forthwith
And highede aghen blive.Ghurried [back] again quickly
The seG bigan to throgheGsea toss
The knave there gan adrinke:Gwas drowned
The see him con ded throweGdid cast him dead
Of the hus ther heoG was in,house where she
If heo oghtG of Horn isighe:Ganything could see
Tho fond heo the knave adrent,Gdrowned
That heo hadde for Horn isent,
Horn cam to Thurston the King
Tho he was iknoweGThen he [Thurston] was made aware
That Rimenhild was his oghe;G[Horn’s] own
OfG his gode kenneG[Horn told him] of kin
And huG he sloghG in feldehow killed
That his fader quelde,GThe one who killed
That thu noght ne linne:Gmay you not fail me
And I schal do to spuseGbring about the marriage of
Thi doghter wel to huse:Gi.e., into a good family
Heo schal to spuseG havefor a husband
GodG knight midG the besteGood among
That to schupe droghe.Ggot on board
Horn dude him in the weieGgot underway
The wind him gan to blowe
Hi strike seilG and mastelower sail
Or enyG day was sprungeBefore another
Ne mighte he come no latere.
His folk he dude abideGcaused to wait
Under wude side.GAt the edge of the woods
AlsoG he sprunge ofG stone.N As if out of
That heo ne weopG with ighe.Gwept eyes
TheghG he were ut of londe.Even if
Ther I was atte yate,Gat the gate
Nolde hiG me in late.Gthey let
To bureG that me hire ladde:GTo a chamber men led her
Away I gan glide:GI snuck away
That deolG I nolde abide.Gsorrow endure
Quath Horn, “So Crist me rede,GAs Christ commands me
We schulle chaungi wede.N Gexchange clothing
And takG me thi sclavyne,Ggive cloak
ThatG some hit schulle ofthinke.”GSo that regret
His sclavyn he dude dun legge,Glay down
And tok hit on his rigge,Gback
That nere him noght lothe.Gwere not displeasing to him
Horn tok burdonG and scrippeGstaff bag
He makede him a ful chere,Gfoul appearance
And al bicolmedeG his swere.Gdirtied neck
HesG he nas nevremore ilich.GAs never before like that
Horn gan to the yateG turnegate
The boyeG hit scholde abugge.Gbastard pay for it
Horn threw him over the briggeGbridge
And sutheG com in atte gate.afterwards
Ase heo were of witte,Gout of her mind
Ne mighte hureG no man wurne.Gher stop
Ne segh heG nowhar walkeNor did he see
That he cuthe knowe.GAs far as he could tell
